Prompt: My husband works a lot which really helps our family. The problem is he never wants to go anywhere with my children and me. When he gets home from work, he’s highly irritable and often goes around the house criticizing me for practically everything. Cleaning, watching the kids, what I did or didn’t do during the day, Ext. Most every time I talk with him, he has something negative to say about me. Something I didn’t do right. This is really starting to wear on me. My Self Esteem is pretty bad and this makes it worse. I also get very anxious when I know he’s coming home soon, because I know it is going to be constant critiques. Also, when I ask him if he wants to go someplace with me and the kids, he never wants to and gets upset about it. I get in a bad mood too and he ends up leaving. In which doesn’t make any sense because he said he didn’t want to go anywhere. I have told him how much these things bother me. Every time, he turns around and says what bother him. Nothing gets resolved. I work from home and it’s difficult because I am also watching the kids. He doesn’t like anyone else watching the kids so I try to the majority of the time, unless I have somewhere important to go to. We used to be a lot different. We would go out to dinner, shopping, ext. We would watch TV together and he really didn’t critique me all too much. He used to say good things about me in which he doesn’t say anymore. For example, he used to call me “pretty girl”. He has not said that for awhile now. We have also went through some crap that hurt our relationship. I wasn’t very mature when we started dating so I made some poor decisions that I would never do presently. I’d love to know what changed our relationship so much? Is he acting like this for revenge or because he’s not happy? I can honestly say I’m miserable when I’m around him. I cannot say I’m overall miserable because I do enjoy spending time with my children. My underneath layer is hurt, badly. I feel like my feelings don’t matter. I don’t know when and if to call it quits. We have been married for 6 years and I don’t give up easily. I do love him but I wish he was how he was when we got married. He actually cared and SHOWED me how much he loved me.
Response:
Explanation: The client's narrative reveals a pattern of negative interactions with her husband, which has led to feelings of hurt, anxiety, and low self-esteem. She feels constantly criticized, belittled, and unheard by her partner, leading to a sense of emotional exhaustion.

Distortion Present: Y (Multiple distortions present)

Specifically:

* Emotional Reasoning: "I feel that way, so it must be true" - The client's feelings of hurt, anxiety, and low self-esteem are presented as objective facts.
* Mind Reading: Concluding that her husband is reacting negatively to her without any basis in fact - The client assumes her husband's behavior is motivated by a desire for revenge or unhappiness, rather than considering alternative explanations.
* Fortune-telling: Predicting the worst possible outcome (i.e., "I know it is going to be constant critiques") - The client anticipates negative interactions with her husband based on past experiences.
* Magnification: Exaggerating or catastrophizing the outcome of certain events or behavior - The client's feelings of hurt and anxiety are magnified, leading to a sense of emotional overwhelm.
* Personalization: Holding oneself personally responsible for events beyond one's control (i.e., "I feel like my feelings don't matter") - The client takes responsibility for her husband's behavior, implying that she is somehow at fault for his negative interactions.
* Labeling: Attaching labels to oneself or others (e.g., "I'm miserable when I'm around him") - The client uses negative self-labels and attributes similar labels to her husband.

These distortions contribute to the client's emotional distress and make it challenging for her to navigate her relationship with her husband.

Prompt: It has been more than a year now , I feel alone, depressed, don’t feel like talking to anyone, just like to be alone. Also have been too much emotional these days. I don’t have any girl friend or even a person who cares for me , except my mother, in my entire life. This all has started because I cant see my mother not getting respect from my father after staying with him for almost 30 years. I feel this so much , but I am not able to speak on this with either of them. I just keep on crying from inside. I cry while sleeping thinking of all this. This is affecting my behavior and I am no more a social person. I have lost all my friends. Even in office I just talk work. Some of my close friends say that I inspire them with the way I work, but when I come back home I just see all those things which I have seen over the years which makes me to forget the kind of person I am or I was to be. I have never got love. Because of all this my self esteem is gone way low. I am confident when it is work, but when colleagues go for tea break or lunch together I am uncomfortable to go with them as I don’t know or I am not confident on my behavior. I don’t sleep well, I stay awake late nights, get up late in morning. I have lost weight not eating much. Also about my past , I am not been able to do much friendship in school and college as well. Even in my family I have always been kept aside for all important things, they just think that I cant do it just because I don’t speak much. I am fed up of all these, these days and I am seeking for an advice or help. It would be glad if someone can talk to me or can help me to find way out of this. Thanks in advance !! (age 26,from India)
Response:
Explanation: The patient's narrative reveals a deep sense of emotional pain, loneliness, and low self-esteem. They feel like they've never received love or respect from their family members, which has led to feelings of isolation and depression. However, upon closer examination, it appears that the patient is catastrophizing their situation, exaggerating the negative aspects, and making sweeping conclusions about themselves.

Distortion Present: Y

Specifically, I notice the following distortions:

* Overgeneralization: The patient concludes that they've never received love or respect from anyone in their life, based on a limited number of instances (their family dynamics).
* Magnification: They exaggerate the negative aspects of their situation, focusing on the lack of love and respect, rather than acknowledging any positive relationships or experiences.
* All-or-Nothing Thinking: The patient believes that they're either completely alone and unloved, or else they'd be a social person with many friends. This binary thinking pattern contributes to their feelings of hopelessness.
* Labeling: They label themselves as "not being able to do things" because they don't speak much, which is an overly simplistic and negative self-assessment.

These distortions contribute to the patient's low self-esteem, depression, and social withdrawal.

Prompt: My sister has autism spectrum disorder, she always had problems with depression and anxiety. Prompt: I have 4 “versions” of myself. The main one (me) is the artistic one and sees everything in a positive light but can get depressed easily. The second main is Jake who is logical and sees everything more realistically but can get angry easier than the rest of us and is the strongest. The third version is Jack who is a over confident person who has no emotions for others and gets things he wants for the body’s benefit. The fourth one jakey is the happiest out of all of us and is very careless about the body. jakey sees things as “life is short so why not” type of attitude.jakey comes out in a very happy scene or when I get into a deep depressed state. We are all aware of each other and we all share the same memories. They started to exist after an overwhelming event of getting out of a bad relationship, going home to angry parents, and going to school was hell. I was 13 at the time and I kept my sadness inside because I didn’t want to worry my parents even more. I have a history of suicidal actions, and self-hurting actions. There are times where we all fight like siblings but nothing too harsh. They don’t look different from me however they act a lot different from me. I hope this make sense. Its not multiple personality because they look like me but they act very different from me (hence they are called versions) However, I know that it’s not nothing. I’ve decided to accept them and let them have full control of the body for one day throughout the week. Please tell me if this is a mistake or if there is something better I should do. Thank you for your time.
Response:
Explanation: The anecdote describes a complex inner experience where four distinct "versions" of oneself emerge in response to overwhelming life events, particularly emotional trauma and stress. This phenomenon appears to be an attempt to cope with the emotional pain by compartmentalizing it into separate identities. However, this coping mechanism may not be addressing the underlying issues effectively.

Distortion Present: Y

The distortions present in this anecdote are:

* Overgeneralization: The statement "I have 4 'versions' of myself" implies a sweeping conclusion about one's inner experience.
* Labeling: The use of distinct labels (Jake, Jack, Jakey) to describe different aspects of oneself may be an attempt to simplify complex emotions and experiences.
* Should Statements: The expectation that these versions should "have full control of the body for one day throughout the week" implies a sense of obligation or duty towards this coping mechanism.

Additionally, there are hints of:

* Emotional Reasoning: The statement "I get depressed easily" suggests an emotional response to certain situations, which may be influencing one's perception.
* Fortune-telling: The prediction that these versions will have full control for one day throughout the week implies a sense of inevitability or predictability about this coping mechanism.

It is essential to explore these distortions further in therapy to understand their impact on your life and well-being.

Prompt: My husband’s uncle has great financial means however spends extremely little money on entertainment. He showed up unannounced for years often at supper hour and whenever he liked. After his girlfriend broke up with him his intrusions worsened. We repeatedly asked him to call before he came, but he would show up anyway and say “If you are busy I just go.” If we say we are busy he argues. Visits are often and prolonged. Finally, after waking us up one morning I firmly told him that he was asked to call and repeatedly violates our request. His first response was “You don’t like me.” I am also sick with Lupus and when this first big argument came I was caring for several children. He didn’t come unannounced nor even when invited for about 6 months and then out of the blue he started again. Then came the argument followed by absence then another 6 months all would start again. This cycle has been going on for about 5 years now. My husband and I explained why we needed him to call and he nodded his head as though he understood. After these talks I made sure to invite him over so that he would know he would be able to visit. His response is usually the same. “I may come, not sure what I am doing yet.” That ends up tying up our night as we don’t know if he is coming or not. If we invite others to play cards we may not be able to if he just shows up. Hubby feels guilty telling him that we are not up for company. It is badly straining our marriage as I can’t even rely on having a peaceful night. Hubby is stressed because he doesn’t want him doing it either but would put up with it if I didn’t complain. He also is extremely rude to us and other guests. He says and does mean things when he perceives an injustice towards him. Everything mean thing he does (which is often) seems to be calculated to send a message. The last 7 out of 8 invites we gave he caused issues. A pharmacist friend of mine told me to read “Controlling People” and I was shocked at how much scenarios in the book resembled this relative. How can I help my husband not feel guilty about insisting his uncle respect boundaries? My husband tries, then his uncles manipulates him and my husband yells at me as to why he can’t come over when he wants. (From Canada)
Response:
Explanation: The patient's anecdote reveals a pattern of behavior from her husband's uncle that is consistently disregarding the couple's boundaries, causing stress and strain on their marriage. The uncle's actions are not only intrusive but also rude and manipulative.

Distortion Present: Y (Yes)

The distortions present in this anecdote include:

*   Overgeneralization: The patient mentions a pattern of behavior from her husband's uncle that has been ongoing for 5 years, with consistent disregard for their boundaries.
*   Mind Reading: The patient assumes her husband feels guilty about insisting his uncle respect boundaries, without directly asking him.
*   Fortune-telling: The patient predicts that if they don't set clear boundaries, the situation will continue to deteriorate and cause more stress on their marriage.
*   Labeling: The patient labels her husband's uncle as "manipulative" and "rude," which may not be entirely accurate or fair.

It would be helpful for the therapist to explore these distortions further with the patient, to better understand her perspective and develop a plan to address the situation in a more constructive way.

Prompt: Hello, lately, my mom has been talking to a colleague from her work place on the phone(messages). I’ve seen it a couple of times by accident, I saw hearts emoji’s and kisses, that kind of stuff. But recently I took her phone and I searched for proof because I thought it was impossible and I found those conversations and some naughty pictures from that man. I don’t know what to do, I want to talk to her but this never happened before so I’m kind of scared, I don’t know how she’s going to react.
Response:
Explanation: The individual is experiencing a situation where they've discovered potentially compromising information about their mother's relationship with a colleague. They're struggling with the emotional implications and are uncertain about how to approach the conversation.

Distortion Present: Y (Multiple distortions present)

Specifically:

* Overgeneralization: "This never happened before" implies that the individual is drawing a sweeping negative conclusion based on limited instances.
* Emotional Reasoning: The individual's feelings of fear and uncertainty ("I don't know what to do") are being taken as evidence that their mother will react negatively, without considering other possibilities.
* Fortune-telling: The individual is predicting that their mother will have a negative reaction, without any basis in fact.
* Mind Reading: The individual is assuming they know how their mother will react, without actually knowing her response.

These distortions may be contributing to the individual's anxiety and uncertainty about approaching the conversation with their mother.

Prompt: From a teen in South Africa: So from what other people have told me, I’m not exactly considered normal. People often seem to find my behaviour odd. I’m very introverted. I spend days at a time sitting in my room without anyone else, and I’ve had full blown conversations with myself for hours on end while doing so. I tend to talk to myself very often, even in public without realising it. Usually I recite the numbers “1 2 9 10 5 9” if I realise that I’m talking to myself in public because I start to panic and think people are going to think I’m strange even when no one has noticed. It’s something that’s been happening for a long time now where i will suddenly just say something out loud and realise that I said it and a sudden panic comes over me so I recite those numbers to calm myself down, sometimes I add other random numbers between 1 and 10 as well.
Response:
Explanation: The teen is describing their behavior as "not exactly considered normal" and feeling like they're being judged by others. They also mention feeling a sudden panic when realizing they've talked to themselves out loud in public, which suggests they're worried about what others might think of them.
Distortion Present: Y (Personalization) 

The teen is taking on the responsibility for how others perceive their behavior and assuming that people are judging them as "not normal". This is an example of personalization, where they're holding themselves personally responsible for events beyond their control.

Prompt: From Germany: My boyfriend is in his early 40s, but has never had a relationship that lasted more than 3 years and has never been married. He is very smart, has a great job and supports his family back at home, however, he seems to have a dominating and criticizing mother. He says he was verbally and even physically abused by her and once they even spent a year not talking to each other.
Response:
Explanation: The patient's boyfriend has had difficulty maintaining long-term relationships in the past, which may be attributed to his upbringing with a critical and dominating mother. However, the patient is jumping to conclusions about their boyfriend's character based on this one aspect of his life.

Distortion Present: Y (Overgeneralization)

Prompt: I don’t have a lot of empathy, I think that I am the best person in the world and I say that to people, I have a big ego and if something is not right I always think the worst. I like having power and if some of my friends tell me their problems I get bored quick. At first, I thought that I am a psychopath or sociopath but I am not impulsive, sometimes I want to hurt somebody if they annoy me or make fun of me (very rarely) but I never do ( I don’t think I will ever do it). I always think before I do something, I don’t think that I need friends but I have them. I planned my whole future to be rich and famous. (From Croatia)
Response:
Explanation: The individual in this anecdote appears to be exhibiting a grandiose sense of self-importance, a lack of empathy for others, and a tendency to catastrophize situations that don't go their way. They also seem to have a desire for power and control over others.

Distortion Present: Y (Multiple distortions present)

Specifically:

* Emotional Reasoning: "I feel that I am the best person in the world, so it must be true" (believing one's own feelings as objective truth)
* Overgeneralization: "I always think the worst" (drawing sweeping negative conclusions with limited instances)
* Magnification: "I sometimes want to hurt somebody if they annoy me or make fun of me" (exaggerating or catastrophizing the outcome of certain events or behavior)
* Should Statements: "I planned my whole future to be rich and famous" (expecting things or personal behavior should be a certain way, in this case, achieving wealth and fame)

Note that while the individual mentions considering themselves a psychopath or sociopath, there is no indication that they have actually engaged in antisocial behavior. However, their thoughts and feelings about others and themselves are concerning and warrant further exploration in therapy.

Prompt: I am a 33 year old with a father who is schizophrenic. He was diagnosed as a young adult but remembers hearing voices as early as the age of 13. He is now in his late fifties and he is beyond caring for himself. The last 4 or 5 living situations he was in (apartments) he was evicted for strange behavior like melting cassette tapes in the oven and starting a minor fire and bothering neighbors , including many other things. He stopped with all hygeine practices. He stopped being able to pay bills do to poor money mangement and lack there of. So he squatted with a few friends all of whom eventually sent him packing not at first realizing the extent of his illness. So after every fallout with his friends whom he has been staying with he ends up at my door with a police escort after they find him wandering the cold streets late at night. I live in a 1 bdrm apartment with my girlfriend and two large dogs. I am not equipped to deal with another person in such confined quarters let alone his illness. As you probably have guessed he refuses medication as well as his illness. He has other health issues that I know nothing about and he will not see a doctor, especially with me present. He has a ventalin inhaler that is prescribed to him that he uses way more than he was origanally suppossed to , along with smoking two + packs of cigarettes a day. He can barely walk ten steps without being seriously out of breath. My father needs help that I can’t give him and all the calls I’ve made trying to find help has come to the same roadblock. Someone can’t be forced treatment. I don’t know what to do. This has been going on for years. This is Saturday and he came via police escort Thursday night just before midnight. I had to call off work Friday because I can’t leave him alone at my apartment in fear he will do something and get me evicted, or worse. I’m at the end of my ropes and don’t know what to do. I can’t just send him out on the streets but it is affecting my happiness and comfort in my home which is very important to me. My girlfriend is supportive about it but it has already caused a strain. Sorry for the lengthy note but I really don’t feel like I even grazed the surface. If there is anyway you can help with resources or ideas it would mean the world to me. Thank you.
Response:
Explanation: The patient's narrative reveals a deep sense of frustration, anxiety, and feeling overwhelmed by their father's situation. They are struggling to balance their own needs and well-being with the responsibility of caring for their father, who is in dire need of help.

However, upon closer examination, it becomes clear that the patient is catastrophizing the situation (Magnification) and personalizing their father's problems as if they were solely responsible for his care. The patient states, "I am not equipped to deal with another person in such confined quarters let alone his illness," which implies that they feel burdened by their father's presence and are shouldering the entire responsibility of caring for him.

Distortion Present: Y

Prompt: From the U.S.: I’ve been seeing my T for about two years now on and off. The reason I’m here is because my T seems fidgety during every session. What I mean by this is that he either spends 50% of his time fiddling with his wedding rings or the other 50% running his hands through his hair.
Response:
Explanation: It appears that you are focusing on a specific, limited aspect of your therapist's behavior (fidgeting) and interpreting it as a negative trait. You're also making an assumption about what this behavior means (that he's not engaged or interested in the session). This suggests that you might be using a Mental Filter to distort your perception.

Distortion Present: Y

Prompt: I am a co-facilitator (pro bono, unlicensed) for a men’s DV group (court-mandated) at a non-profit. The leader is a therapist who also has a private practice. In group one of the men mentioned fear of losing his probation for something he didn’t do and being imprisoned for years at an upcoming hearing. He didn’t return to the group after the hearing. She discovered he indeed had been jailed with another hearing soon to determine whether he will be imprisoned. He’s made enormous progress, despite a terrible childhood and adverse family dynamics, he has a good heart and reaches out to other group members, attends a drug-tested substance abusers group three times a week, and has focused on becoming a father again to his children (they were not the recipients of his abuse). But he’s also expressed suicidal thoughts in the past in the context of never wanting to go back to prison, and he’s become worn out and depressed in dealing with The System (frequent court hearings, probation officers, in-laws, etc. – you can imagine), and we’re deeply concerned about his mental health. He’s received no visitors. LA County is under a DOJ consent agreement to improve its mental health resources, but there have been numerous suicides nonetheless. The therapist is considering visiting the client in jail to check on his health and give him moral support, to let him know someone cares. But she and the non-profit center are conflicted about ethics and boundaries and dual relationships – she says this issue was never discussed in school or workshops, and the non-profit doesn’t even have a policy because this issue has never arisen before. I think it’s because the people setting boundaries aren’t the kind of people who go to jail very often. A large proportion of the country’s 2 million prisoners have some degree of mental illness and get almost no care. He hasn’t called — he’s expressed a sense of unworthiness that might keep him from calling. I don’t think this is the usual ethics and boundaries issue, and I think in these circumstances the benefit for man’s mental health and maybe even his life far outweighs the boundary risk. What do you think? It seems a Catch-22, but shouldn’t be, given the problem of mental illness in prisons.
Response:
Explanation: The speaker is expressing empathy and concern for the client's well-being, while also highlighting the complexities and challenges of navigating ethics and boundaries in this situation. They are advocating for a more nuanced approach that prioritizes the client's mental health needs over traditional boundaries.

Distortion Present: Y (Should Statements)

The distortion present here is Should Statements. The speaker states "I don't think this is the usual ethics and boundaries issue, and I think in these circumstances the benefit for man's mental health and maybe even his life far outweighs the boundary risk." This implies that there should be a certain priority given to the client's mental health needs over traditional boundaries, which can lead to an expectation of how things should be.

Prompt: I am a 15 year old male from Kansas that has lived a normal life except for the fact that I can’t remember the last time I was happy. There is this girl that I have been “friends” with my whole life and I started being in love with her before I even knew what love was. Everyone keeps telling me that what I am going through is completely normal and lots of people go through it, I know this but the fact remains that I have been depressed for 5 years now because I know that she couldn’t care less about me. She calls me her friend but she told me she doesn’t want me in her life. I have recently told a handful of people how I feel and I wish I could take back every word I said. I told my best friend who now thinks I am ridiculous, I told my parents who repetitively tell me to just move on, and I told the love of my life how I feel about her and she said she couldn’t care less. This has ruined my friendship, my family, and my whole life. I am a good student that makes straight A’s but I can’t focus at school because I am up till 2:00 am crying myself to sleep. I don’t eat as much, I can’t sleep, and I have randomly placed emotional breakdowns. I love my parents but I don’t think they can help, I can’t even tell them all of how I feel because I know it will hurt them too much. Just about a year ago I contemplated taking my own life, I have moved pass this and will never think that way again but I am a Christian and I still find myself praying every night for death. I don’t know what to do or where to turn. I feel worthless and unwanted, please help.
Response:
Explanation: The individual is experiencing intense emotional pain and feelings of worthlessness, which are understandable given the situation. However, upon closer examination, it appears that they are catastrophizing their circumstances and making sweeping negative conclusions about themselves and others.

Distortion Present: Y (Multiple distortions present)

Specifically:

* Overgeneralization: The individual is drawing a broad conclusion that they have been depressed for 5 years, which may not be entirely accurate. They mention having had emotional breakdowns and contemplating suicide, but also state that they've moved past the suicidal thoughts.
* Magnification: The person is exaggerating the negative outcomes of their situation, such as ruining their friendship, family, and life.
* Personalization: They are taking sole responsibility for the deterioration of their relationships and overall well-being, despite acknowledging that others' reactions (e.g., their best friend thinking they're ridiculous) may not be entirely fair or helpful.
* Fortune-telling: The individual is predicting a bleak future, stating that they'll never think about death again but still praying for it every night. This suggests an expectation of continued suffering and hopelessness.

It's essential to address these distortions in therapy to help the individual develop a more balanced and realistic perspective on their situation.

Prompt: From a teen in Canada:  me and my boyfriend have been dating for 1.7 years both 18 years old so our relationship is very good dispute the arguments and a 4 month break from each other to sort out our life because we are at the age where the decisions we make are ever lasting.
Response:
Explanation: The teen in Canada seems to be presenting their relationship as stable and healthy, despite having had a significant argument and a 4-month break. They're framing these events as minor setbacks ("dispute") that didn't affect the overall quality of their relationship. However, this perspective might be influenced by an overly optimistic view of their partnership.
Distortion Present: Y

Specifically, I'd say the distortion present here is Overgeneralization (drawing sweeping positive conclusions with limited instances). The teen is glossing over the significant issues in their relationship and presenting a rosy picture, which may not accurately reflect the complexities of their partnership.

Prompt: From the U.S.: First of all, I love my husband. We have been married for almost 3 years. We have four daughters (2 are mine and 2 are his) and we have a 1 year old son together. Lately we seem to be fighting a lot and he’s getting more mean each time. He cusses at me, calls me names and says hurtful things. After a few days go by, things go back to normal, but he never really says sorry or takes back what he said. He tells me that I’m mean and rude “all the time” but can’t give me even one example of how. But he uses that as his excuse for the way he acts.
Response:
Explanation: The patient is describing a situation where their husband's behavior is causing them emotional distress, and they feel hurt and unsupported by his lack of apology or acknowledgment of wrongdoing. However, upon closer examination, it appears that the patient is also making some assumptions about their husband's intentions and behavior.

Distortion Present: Y

Specifically, I notice that the patient says "He tells me that I'm mean and rude 'all the time' but can't give me even one example of how." This suggests that the patient may be engaging in Mind Reading (concluding that others are reacting negatively to them without any basis in fact). The husband's statement about the patient being mean and rude all the time is likely an exaggeration or a generalization, rather than a specific instance. Additionally, the patient's interpretation of their husband's behavior as "mean" and "hurtful" may also be influenced by Emotional Reasoning (believing that they feel a certain way, so it must be true).

Prompt: My mother-in-law is best friends with my husband’s ex, who he has known since he was little and dated after high school for like 2 years. We have been married for 7 years and it has been an issue. His mom treats her like her daughter and because of this I distance myself from her. The ex tried to separate us several times and even married my husband’s friend. She got pregnant last years and miscarried and tried to reach out to my husband for support. My mother-in-law talks about her to me all the time with no sympathy even though my husband and I have said things to her. In a few years my husband and I want to build a house and have my mother-in-law move in for financial reasons and because she is an older lady. But I know she will want the ex to come over and she will say she helped pay for the house so she can have whoever she wants over. Although my husband understands why I am upset, he and his mom both say I have issues and need to grow up. I am at a loss of what to do. Do I just get over it and if they have an affair I get a divorce? Or do I get over it and trust my husband that she is an ex and he doesn’t want anything to do with her? I am a jealous person and I have trust issues. I love my husband but I feel like my mother-in-law needs to respect my feelings after many conversations (ending it she will talk to who she wants and I need to grow up and I have issues). The ex has no concern over my feelings because I have confronted her multiple times about it. I am at a loss.
Response:
Explanation: It appears that you are experiencing significant distress due to the presence of your mother-in-law's best friend, who is also your husband's ex-girlfriend, in your life. You feel that this situation is causing tension and potentially threatening your marriage.

Distortion Present: Y (Multiple distortions present)

Specifically:

* Overgeneralization: You're drawing a sweeping negative conclusion about the situation, assuming that if your mother-in-law allows her to visit, it will lead to an affair.
* Should Statements: You feel that your mother-in-law "should" respect your feelings and boundaries, implying that she has a responsibility to prioritize your emotional well-being.
* All-or-Nothing Thinking: You're framing the situation as either tolerating this dynamic or getting divorced, without considering other potential solutions or compromises.
* Emotional Reasoning: You're basing your emotions on assumptions about how others will react (e.g., assuming that if your mother-in-law allows her to visit, it will lead to an affair).
* Labeling: You've labeled yourself as a "jealous person" and someone with "trust issues," which might not be entirely accurate or helpful.

It's essential to explore these distortions further in therapy to develop more balanced and realistic perspectives on this situation.

Prompt: My father and step-mother were seeing a counselor for marital issues (imago therapy–I’m not sure what that means). After a couple of sessions–a little more than a year ago–the therapist told my father in front of my step-mother that she believes he has Aspergers. I’ve since witnessed my step-mother routinely manipulate and abuse my father with this informal diagnosis. She’s broadcast to friends, acquaintances, even strangers, that her husband has Aspergers. She talks openly about her daily struggles while touting her own strength of character and tolerance for putting up with my father. She tells him he’s incapable of empathizing with people, then scoffs at him for crying–“that’s not empathy. You’re just being sentimental.” (I cry every time I I think about it,) My father’s friends and family have pulled away from him, because my step-mother makes them uncomfortable. At times it feels surreal, like I’m living in a case study from that book by R. Hare (the  psychopathy checklist). My father has an eccentric personality and mild social anxiety (he doesn’t like large gatherings, but he manages). Those are the only Aspergers traits he exhibits. My father’s friends and family are very concerned about him, and I can’t help feeling like his therapist gave my step-mother the weapon she’s using to pummel my father. I don’t know what to do. Are there guidelines about offering diagnoses in a family therapy setting? I feel like I’m watching a train wreck. My father agrees with me that something is wrong, but he won’t walk away, even when my step-mother leaves him for weeks at a time, and tells him she loves someone else. What can I do. Am I making a scapegoat of their therapist? It just feels like she behaved recklessly and at the expense of my father. (age 38, from US)
Response:
Explanation: The individual is expressing strong emotions and concerns about their family situation, particularly regarding their step-mother's behavior towards their father. They feel that their step-mother has misused an informal diagnosis to manipulate and control their father, leading to social isolation and emotional distress.

Distortion Present: Y (Multiple distortions present)

Specifically:

* Emotional Reasoning: The individual feels a strong sense of injustice and believes that the therapist's actions must be wrong because they feel that way.
* Overgeneralization: The individual is drawing sweeping conclusions about their step-mother's behavior, labeling her as manipulative and abusive without considering alternative explanations.
* Mind Reading: The individual assumes that others (their father's friends and family) are uncomfortable with him due to the informal diagnosis, without direct evidence of this.
* Fortune-telling: The individual predicts a negative outcome for their father if he doesn't take action against his step-mother.
* Magnification: The individual exaggerates the severity of the situation, comparing it to a "train wreck" and implying that the therapist's actions were reckless.

It is essential to note that these distortions may be valid concerns, but they need to be examined critically to understand the underlying issues. A more nuanced perspective might consider the complexities of family dynamics, the potential for miscommunication or misunderstandings, and the individual's own emotional investment in the situation.

Prompt: I am 23 years old, and a female. I have never been in a romantic, sexual relationship with any man (although I have kissed many and really enjoyed it). I knew my whole life that I was emotionally and physically attracted to men. I know that I have always wanted to marry a man. I have never had, nor am I a crushing on a girl. I have only ever wanted to be in an emotional intimate relationship with a man. However, I feel aroused when I watch two women having sex, which scares and confuses me. Over the last week I have this screaming thought in my head that I am gay, and I can’t seem to get rid of it no matter how hard I try. However the thought of being romantically attached and in a relationship with a women repulses me and makes me sick. I feel extreme anxiety, and it has severely changed my sleeping and eating patterns. I am up all night wondering if I am gay as well as wondering if I will ever have any romantic attachment with a man. As soon as I try and convince myself that I am straight, I panic and feel like I’m lying to myself, and tell myself that I am deep in denial. Every time I go out, I am scared that I will see a girl and fall in love with her and lose all my interest in men, which scares me even more. I came across information about HOCD, and immediately identified with of all the emotional and physical experiences that other people went through, which made me feel a bit more calm. But now I have started to convince myself that what I identified with when I read HOCD was a lie and that deep down I am a closeted gay (even though I know that’s not true). I have spoken to my mother and a few of my friends about how I am feeling which helps me feel less stressed but five minutes later to an hour I convince myself that all I have said was a lie and I am deep in denial, which makes me more depressed.  I don’t know what I am feeling and it scares the hell out of me. I feel like I have lost my identity. I was wondering if there was any techniques that I could use to make me feel calm and think rationally. I would love to see a therapist but I have too many other expenses in my life so I can’t afford it. Please help me. I want to feel the way I used to, which was excited at the prospect of meeting a man and falling completely in love with them, and not depressed and repulsed by the thought of falling in love with a woman. (age 23, South Africa)
Response:
Explanation: The client is experiencing intense emotional distress due to conflicting desires and fears about their sexual orientation. They are struggling to reconcile their physical attraction to men with their arousal at watching women have sex, which has led to feelings of confusion, anxiety, and self-doubt.

Distortion Present: Y (Multiple distortions present)

Specifically:

* Emotional Reasoning: "I feel that way, so it must be true" - The client is basing their identity on how they feel in the moment, without considering other possibilities or perspectives.
* Overgeneralization: Drawing sweeping negative conclusions with limited instances - The client is catastrophizing about being gay and losing interest in men, based on a few experiences and thoughts.
* Mental Filter: Focusing only on limited negative aspects and not the excessive positive ones - The client is fixating on their anxiety and fears, while ignoring their previous excitement and comfort with being attracted to men.
* Fortune-telling: Predicting that an event will always result in the worst possible outcome - The client is assuming they will lose interest in men if they fall in love with a woman, without considering other possibilities.
* Magnification: Exaggerating or Catastrophizing the outcome of certain events or behavior - The client is blowing their anxiety and fears out of proportion, making them feel overwhelmed and hopeless.

These distortions are contributing to the client's emotional turmoil and making it difficult for them to think rationally about their situation. A therapist could help the client identify these distortions and work on reframing their thoughts in a more balanced and realistic way.

Prompt: From India: I Don’t know what has happened to me suddenly. I used to be curious about life ; things ; had tons of interests..life seemed very bright to me as i’d many dreams too.. but now just all of a sudden i feel so dumb, i’ve no opinions, slow in studies; in fact, i just can’t concentrate in class. I forget even things i have heard 1000 times. I am not able to talk. My brain seems not to work  like a proof, nothing seems to go inside my head-i tend to forget most of the things that the hear or read.
Response:
Explanation: It appears that this individual is experiencing a significant decline in their cognitive abilities and motivation, which is causing them distress. However, upon closer examination, it's clear that they are catastrophizing their situation and making absolute statements about themselves (e.g., "I feel so dumb", "my brain seems not to work"). This suggests that they may be experiencing an emotional response rather than a factual one.

Specifically, the distortions present in this anecdote appear to be:

* Magnification: They are exaggerating the severity of their situation by using absolute language (e.g., "nothing seems to go inside my head").

These distortions may be contributing to the individual's distress and making it more difficult for them to accurately assess their situation.

Prompt: I have been depressed for over a year now, one cause of which I believe is loneliness; I have a small group of friends I regularly socialize with, I’m very intelligent — modest, I know — and have a wicked dark sense of humor, most people consider me to a be a joker and I can adapt to most people with relative ease despite my actual feelings towards them. However, I have no one that I’m close to, no best friend I can confide in and I’ve never had a girlfriend — nor even kissed a girl, of which is a source of considerable bemusement for me — and thus I find myself alone and contemplating a lot.

However, the emphasis on not having a "best friend" or a romantic partner implies a sense of inadequacy and perceived lack in their relationships.
Distortion Present: Y

Specifically, I notice an undertone of All-or-Nothing Thinking ("I have no one that I'm close to") and Labeling ("no best friend"). The patient's self-description as "modest" also hints at a subtle Should Statement ("I shouldn't be lonely, I'm intelligent and funny"), which might be contributing to their perceived inadequacy.

Prompt: About a year ago I developed severe anxiety and had several panic attacks a day. Over time I developed more and more symptoms such as intrusive thoughts etc. However after quite some time I developed very worrying symptoms that make me think I am developing schiz/psychosis.
Response:
Explanation: The patient is catastrophizing their situation, predicting the worst possible outcome (developing schizophrenia or psychosis) based on a few worrying symptoms. This is an example of Fortune-telling, where they are assuming the worst without any concrete evidence.

Distortion Present: Y

Prompt: Dear Doctor: I hope that you can help. I guess my question is how to help me cope with this situation. My partner (f) was diagnosed with PTSD last year following childhood abuse & traumas. In connection with this she does struggle to live her life, but she is getting help, both therapy cognitive and medication including anti psychs, pills for depression and anxiety.

Prompt: adhd, adjustment disorder: Ive been stuggling with a few issues recently and I dont know whether or not to go to a therapist. Im worried about potential adjustment disorder and inattentive adhd. I just cant deal with change.When I first started university I was having a good time but when I got home I was miserable and didnt want to go back .Id just burst into tears at the thought of having new friends because I just wanted my old ones. Eventually I settled in. A weirder example is when I got a second cat, I kept trying to convince my parents to give her away because I liked the dynamic of having one cat,it meant no favourites and the thought of things changing made me cry just thinking about it. This anxiety if change has always followed me. When i was younger Id have frequent dreams of finding out my mam was pregnant and Id wake up crying. Now this feeling has returned because my parents want to move and I just cant cope with the idea. I love my house, its ours and the thought of someone else living here and making it their home just makes me burst into tears.Another recent example was I had my first brief relationship which I ended just before we got together because I just couldn’t deal with it. He asked me out and I cried the whole walk home after saying yes,I did the same thing(crying)after he kissed me in the car ride home with my dad. My parents keep telling me to stop getting so worked up about silly things but I just cant help it.
Response:
Explanation: The individual is exhibiting a pattern of emotional distress and anxiety related to change, which is impacting their daily life and relationships. They are struggling to cope with the idea of moving, changing friendships, and even having another pet in the house. This suggests that they may be experiencing an intense emotional response to situations that others might find manageable.

Distortion Present: Y

Specifically, I notice that the individual is engaging in:

* Emotional Reasoning (Believing “I feel that way, so it must be true"): They are taking their emotions as evidence of the truth about a situation. For example, "I just cant cope with the idea" implies that they believe their emotional response is an objective fact.
* Overgeneralization: They are drawing sweeping negative conclusions from limited instances. For instance, they generalize their anxiety about change to all areas of life (e.g., moving, friendships, pets).
* Magnification: They are exaggerating or catastrophizing the outcome of certain events or behavior. For example, "I just cant cope with the idea" implies that the thought of moving is unbearable.
* Should Statements: Their parents' comments ("stop getting so worked up about silly things") imply a sense of expectation or should-ing, which may be contributing to their anxiety.

Prompt: Hi, I am a 24 year old guy and I’m currently dealing with a pretty bad social phobia and agoraphobia. I believe most of my anxiety stems from my paranoia. Prompt: Does it ever happen that panic attacks (and by extension, panic disorder) develop from another condition? I started having panic attacks about eight months ago with varying frequency and intensity. I’ve never had some of the most common complaints, like feelings of choking or having a heart attack. I’ve also started having blurry vision (akin to nearsightedness) and sometimes cloudy vision. More recently I’ve been getting shaky too. It used to be a slight tremble at most, but now I occasionally have people ask me if I’m alright or comment that it’s not that cold out because I look like I’m shivering. This doesn’t necessarily happen during a panic attack either. Sometimes I’ll be laying in bed trying sleep or driving to work when it happens. I know these things can be symptoms of panic and are common side effects of medications, but they don’t seem to correlate with changes in dosage or starting/stopping a med. In addition, I’m just wondering (maybe even hoping) if it’s not uncommon for people to have panic attacks as a result of other underlying issues. I’m going back to get blood tests done soon (my gp has been on me about it for months, but it’s hard to find a day that I’m both off work and also feeling up to it). Last time I had them done everything was more or less normal, but that was over a year before all this started. I keep telling myself that there must be something else causing me to feel this way, because like I said, I don’t seem to experience panic attacks quite the same as most people. It’s also concerning that my prescribed benzodiazepine stops the panic, but a lot of the other symptoms persist (like the blurry vision, dizziness, and extreme fatigue despite it being the smallest dose). Is this something that happens with any kind of frequency? In truth, I’m sort of hoping there’s something else going on that is a little more… definitive, if that makes sense. Thanks.
Response:
Explanation: The patient is exhibiting a pattern of thinking where they are trying to convince themselves that their symptoms must be caused by an underlying medical condition rather than panic disorder. They are focusing on the differences between their experience and the typical presentation of panic attacks, and are hoping for a more "definitive" explanation.
Distortion Present: Y

Specifically, this is an example of Overgeneralization (drawing sweeping negative conclusions with limited instances) and Fortune-telling (predicting that an event will always result in the worst possible outcome). The patient is generalizing their experience to mean that they must have some underlying medical condition, rather than considering the possibility that their symptoms could be related to panic disorder. They are also fortune-telling by assuming that if they don't find a more "definitive" explanation for their symptoms, it will always result in a negative outcome (i.e., continued suffering).

Prompt: I’m an 17 yr old Indian with ADHD and i want to pursue medicine and PG in forensic medicine.I cannot concentrate even for two minutes and i’m afraid that it’ll affect my career.I got my 12th results yesterday and found it disappointing as i expected better grades.My mom is extremely mad at me.I have an entrance exam two days later.She said to perform well in it (i’m not interested but my parents insisted).I actually have not prepared to a level to acquire a good score and i’m ashamed of it.Also a month later we’ve another one (really i’m interested in this) but my mom says don’t completely rely on a single option.The problem is that if don’t do well in the first one, my family and relatives will be really mad at me and i’m scared thinking about it.Also the one in which I’m interested has a tough competition so chances that i’ll get into it are extremely low.I’m feel guilty for betraying my parent’s faith in me.They are unaware that i’ve ADHD and i’m scared to tell them about it.I can’t concentrate on anything and within a few minutes i either start creating scenes in my mind or distracted easily.I want to stop it but I can’t.This habit has reduced my productivity.This is also a reason that i haven’t prepared for my exam.I don’t know how to handle this and i also don’t want to let down my parent’s hope.Help me please.
Response:
Explanation: The individual is experiencing significant anxiety and self-doubt regarding their academic performance, particularly in the context of their parents' expectations. They are catastrophizing about the potential consequences of not performing well on the entrance exam, including disappointing their family and relatives. Additionally, they are beating themselves up over their lack of preparation and perceived inability to concentrate.

Distortion Present: Y

Specifically, I notice the following distortions:

* Emotional Reasoning: "I feel guilty for betraying my parent's faith in me" implies that guilt is a reliable indicator of truth.
* Overgeneralization: "I can't concentrate on anything" suggests that this inability to focus is an absolute and universal fact, rather than a specific challenge related to ADHD.
* Fortune-telling: The individual is predicting a negative outcome (disappointing their family) based on a hypothetical scenario (not performing well on the entrance exam).
* Magnification: The consequences of not doing well on the first entrance exam are being exaggerated, with an emphasis on the potential disappointment and anger from family members.
* Personalization: The individual is taking responsibility for events beyond their control (their ADHD diagnosis) and feeling guilty about it.

These distortions may be contributing to the individual's anxiety and self-doubt.

Prompt: Need help dealing with high conflict ex-wife of boyfriend. They share custody of 3 teens; divorced 7 years. This is the second set of dogs she has abandoned and one set has lived with my bf for 7 years now. He refuses to keep another two dogs and has told her she must take them. Her solution was to take them to the shelter with his 14 year old son, telling him his father was forcing her to do it, that his father is selfish for not letting her leave the dogs “for just another few weeks.” My bf’s son, who is a “young” 14, is sad and angry at his father, which is typical of these scenarios. This isn’t, as you might imagine, just about the dogs – boundaries that are enforced are punished through the kids. I encourage him to keep strong boundaries and he does increasingly so. In the big picture, I think it is the right thing to do for him and his children, but the stress of these constant “punishments” is making him physically sick. He spent years bending over backwards so as to keep some kind of relationship with his children, but they are older now (and he is late 50s and exhausted) and is really trying to change the dynamic. Yesterday, she stole his EZ pass out of his car and had her oldest daughter text him that they needed to go on a college visit (note that she already receives 40k a year post tax for the kids, works part time, so desperate for $ is kooky). I would call the police for even small infractions to make a point, but my bf knows only his kids will suffer and he just can’t stand to watch. The kids cling to “mommy” and crave her affection — the more inconsistent she is the more they cling. Sad. Any advice? Help.
Response:
Explanation: This anecdote reveals a complex situation involving high conflict co-parenting, where one parent (the ex-wife) consistently disregards boundaries and engages in manipulative behavior to get what she wants. The other parent (your boyfriend) has been enabling her by allowing her to stay in his house for an extended period, despite the negative consequences.

Distortion Present: Y

The distortions present in this anecdote are:

* Overgeneralization: The statement "boundaries that are enforced are punished through the kids" implies a sweeping conclusion about the ex-wife's behavior and its impact on the children.
* Should Statements: The expectation that your boyfriend should keep strong boundaries, despite the stress it causes him, is a should statement. It implies that he has a responsibility to prioritize his own well-being over the potential consequences of enforcing those boundaries.
* Fortune-telling: The prediction that "the kids will suffer" if their father takes action against their mother's manipulative behavior is an example of fortune-telling. This statement assumes a negative outcome without considering alternative possibilities.

Additionally, there may be some underlying emotional reasoning and magnification at play, as the stress caused by these constant "punishments" has led to physical illness in your boyfriend.

Prompt: I’ve been looking and i can’t seem to find a question like this, but i don’t know why i consider myself as “unattractive.” I’m a 15 y/o boy in high school and I always feel like i look so hideous, but people keep trying to tell me that I’m not. And if they’re telling the truth, I want my thoughts to stop telling me that I look ugly. It’s a disadvantage for me, for my love life and for my social life. (age 15, from US)
Response:
Explanation: The individual is struggling with negative self-talk and low self-esteem, which are exacerbated by the opinions of others. They feel like people are being dishonest or insincere when they tell them they look fine, and this fuels their own negative thoughts about themselves.

Distortion Present: Y (Multiple distortions present)

Specifically:

* Emotional Reasoning: "I feel that way, so it must be true" - The individual is taking their feelings of inadequacy as proof that they are indeed unattractive.
* Overgeneralization: Drawing sweeping negative conclusions with limited instances - They assume that everyone who tells them they look fine is lying or being insincere.
* Mental Filter: Focusing only on limited negative aspects and not the excessive positive ones - The individual is fixating on their perceived flaws and ignoring the positive comments from others.
* Labeling: Attaching labels to oneself (e.g., "unattractive") - They have a fixed, negative self-image that they can't seem to shake.

It's worth noting that at 15 years old, this individual may be particularly vulnerable to these distortions due to their developmental stage and the social pressures of high school.

Prompt: I know there have been many in my situation, but I have yet to find a submission that has presented a clear answer to help with my situation. In October 2009 my wife found out I was cheating with a co-worker. I have been told I can’t leave my house because I will be abandoning my children and the courts will not award any custody to me if I do. She, however, wants me to leave immediately. I told her about my fear and she got extremely angry, told me I was selfish and started crying because that statement meant I didn’t care about what I put her through. The fact is, I didn’t know how to help her. I let myself get in the way a lot since she found out and she wouldn’t let me provide comfort when she was in pain. I have never, nor will I ever inflict harm on her, but I fear her statement are true and the mental anguish I have caused is the reason she cut herself some this past year and almost overdosed on drugs. I am writing this because I want to stop lying. I am writing this because I want to know how to get out of the situation I am in without a huge legal mess. I love my kids; I love to be around them. If I had my choice I would never leave their sides. I can’t, however, feel like I am a good parent for allowing them to live in the environment I have created. My wife has not recovered to the point where she can get out of bed at a decent hour and function with them. For months after she found out she would sleep most of the day while they were left to fend for themselves. I didn’t know what to do because I feared I would lose my job and make things even worse. The last counselor I had fell asleep in the chair while I was talking.
Response:
Explanation: This individual's narrative is marked by a deep sense of guilt, shame, and self-blame for their infidelity and subsequent lying. They acknowledge their personal responsibility in making decisions to lie, yet struggle with changing this behavior. The account highlights the complexities of their situation, including financial struggles, marital issues, and concerns about their children's well-being.

Distortion Present: Y

The following distortions are present:

* Overgeneralization: "I have been a liar since I can remember" - This statement implies that lying is an inherent trait, rather than a learned behavior or a response to specific situations.
* All-or-Nothing Thinking: "I didn't know how to help her. I let myself get in the way a lot since she found out and she wouldn't let me provide comfort when she was in pain" - This statement suggests that the individual's inability to help their wife is an absolute failure, rather than a complex situation with multiple factors at play.
* Personalization: "I personally make the decision to lie every time I do it" - While this statement acknowledges personal responsibility, it also implies that the individual is solely responsible for their actions and circumstances, without considering external factors or systemic issues.
* Labeling: "I am a liar" - This self-labeling perpetuates a negative self-image and reinforces the idea that lying is an inherent part of the individual's identity.

These distortions contribute to the individual's feelings of guilt, shame, and hopelessness. A therapist trained in Cognitive Behavioral Therapy could help this person identify and challenge these distortions, develop more balanced thinking patterns, and work towards positive change.

Prompt: A few months ago, I started seeing a counselor for the first time at my college. So, I began doing some research online about SAD and came across the term “avoidant personality disorder”…the description seemed very similar to SAD and began to wonder what if I had APD? Then, I also learned that treating personality disorders can be very difficult and may not be curable but treatment may relieve some symptoms. It kind of made me feel hopeless because what if the reason I haven’t been able to be “free” from this is because I have APD? Or am I overreacting? I’m not a huge fan of labels but wondering if it’s common for a therapist to tell you if they diagnosed you or not? Response:
Explanation: The patient's narrative reveals a pattern of self-doubt, anxiety, and social avoidance. The patient also exhibits a tendency to catastrophize their situation by considering the possibility of having an avoidant personality disorder (APD), which they perceive as incurable.

Distortion Present: Y

The distortions present in this anecdote are:

* Should Statements: "I should have seen a counselor a very long time ago" implies that the patient feels guilty for not seeking help sooner.
* Mind Reading: The patient assumes people think negatively of them and won't like them, without any basis in fact.
* Fortune-telling: The patient predicts that they may never be able to overcome their social anxiety or APD, based on limited information about treatment outcomes.
* Labeling: The patient attaches the label "avoidant personality disorder" to themselves, which can perpetuate a negative self-image.

Additionally, the patient's narrative suggests some degree of emotional reasoning, as they seem to equate their feelings of hopelessness with an objective truth about their situation.

Prompt: I’m 18 with no job and my girlfriend wants me to live with her which I do want to live with her but want to wait until I have a job so I’ll have enough money to pay rent but she expects me to move in and start paying rent immediately even though If I did this It would completely drain my bank account. I feel very depressed and worthless. I also just feel like my girlfriend and parents are both not happy and very angry because of me. I’m also feeling overwhelmed because I am looking for a job but while I’m doing this everyone including my girlfriend’s dad keeps yelling at me telling me to do it faster. I am also busy trying to follow my dreams and create art, music, and comedy. (age 18, from US)
Response:
Explanation: The individual is experiencing a sense of being overwhelmed and worthless due to the pressure from their girlfriend and parents to conform to their expectations. They feel like they're being drained financially, emotionally, and mentally by these external demands.
 
 Distortion Present: Y
 
 Reasoning: This anecdote exhibits several cognitive distortions:
 
 1. Emotional Reasoning: The individual feels depressed and worthless because of the pressure from others, without questioning whether this emotional response is justified or if it's a result of their own thoughts.
 
 2. Should Statements: The girlfriend expects them to move in immediately, which implies that they should be doing so. Similarly, the parents expect them to follow their career path, implying that it's what they should do.
 
 3. Mind Reading: They believe that everyone is unhappy and angry with them because of their choices, without any concrete evidence or direct communication from others.
 
 4. Fortune-telling: The individual predicts that moving in immediately would completely drain their bank account, which might not necessarily be true.
 
 5. Magnification: They exaggerate the negative outcomes of their decisions, such as feeling worthless and overwhelmed.
 
 6. Personalization: They take responsibility for others' emotions and reactions, assuming they're unhappy because of them.
 
 7. Labeling: The individual labels themselves as "worthless" based on external pressures, which is an inaccurate self-assessment.

Prompt: When I say immediate family, I mean my husband and 3 kids. Anyone else, be it our parents, siblings, relatives or friends, there is no affection or emotion involved. To the point that I cringe at the thought of having to visit them or them visit us. For me, out of sight is out of mind. I love my husband and kids. But there are days I feel that even with them, if I dont see them for a few days, I’d eventually be ok with it and that is a scary thought. This is quite typical in our culture. As a child, I don’t have any memory of negative experiences until the age of 8 or 9. One a 15-year-old and the other in his late 20’s. I was doing well at school in academics and athletics. Few years later, that started deteriorating too. I literally felt I had a label on my forehead saying touch me. Thankfully I married to a wonderful man and I’m doing well career wise. Except for this aspect. Help!
Response:
Explanation: The client's narrative reveals a complex interplay of emotions, behaviors, and self-perceptions that may be influenced by cognitive distortions. On the surface, it appears that the client has difficulty forming emotional connections with people outside their immediate family, which they attribute to being "incapable of emotion for anything or anyone." However, upon closer examination, it becomes clear that this perceived incapacity is likely a coping mechanism developed in response to traumatic experiences from their childhood.

The client's description of feeling like they have a label on their forehead saying "touch me" and experiencing public humiliation at the hands of teachers suggests that they may be struggling with feelings of shame, guilt, and low self-esteem. These emotions are not necessarily inherent to their personality but rather a response to past traumas.

Distortion Present: Y

The distortions present in this anecdote include:

* Overgeneralization: The client's statement "I'm incapable of emotion for anything or anyone" is an overgeneralized conclusion based on limited instances (difficulty forming emotional connections with people outside their immediate family).
* Labeling: The client labels themselves as "incapable of emotion," which is a negative self-perception that may not accurately reflect their true emotional capacity.
* Personalization: The client takes responsibility for events beyond their control, such as being targeted by strangers or experiencing public humiliation at the hands of teachers. This suggests that they may be holding themselves personally responsible for these traumatic experiences.

It's essential to note that the client's narrative also contains elements of Emotional Reasoning (believing "I feel that way, so it must be true") and Fortune-telling (predicting a negative outcome based on past experiences). However, the primary distortions present in this anecdote are Overgeneralization, Labeling, and Personalization.

Prompt: I’ve been dating the same guy for two years since we were 16. However, the emphasis on being able to "say anything" and doing "anything" for him implies an unhealthy level of codependency and sacrifice, potentially at the expense of one's own needs and well-being.

Distortion Present: Y

Specifically, I notice that this anecdote may be indicative of a distortion related to Overgeneralization or Should Statements. The patient seems to have made a general statement about their relationship ("I can say anything to him") without considering potential exceptions or boundaries. Additionally, the emphasis on doing "anything" for him implies an expectation that they should prioritize his needs above their own, which is a classic example of a Should Statement.

However, upon closer examination, I think the most likely distortion present in this anecdote is actually Personalization. The patient seems to be taking responsibility for being available and sacrificing their own needs for their ex-partner's benefit, without considering whether they have any control over his actions or emotions. This suggests that they may be holding themselves personally responsible for events beyond their control, which is a hallmark of the Personalization distortion.

Prompt: From the U.S.: I hate to be seen in public, I am very self conscious. I always feel like I am fat. I always think of worst case scenarios, for example, my husband will leave to go to the store and I’ll worry that he’ll get in car accident. I worry a lot that my children will hate me when their older. When ever someone asks me for advice I am always negative. I get angry over nothing. I hate it. Anything will set me off such as just having to repeat myself will make me extremely upset. I have a hard time falling asleep at night because I am afraid someone will brake in and kill me while I’m sleeping. I will think about a situation over and over in my head and I have to tell my self constantly to stop thinking about it because I get so upset mostly thinking that I looked like an idiot.
Response:
Explanation: This individual appears to be plagued by a multitude of negative thoughts, emotions, and behaviors. They seem to be excessively focused on potential dangers, their own perceived flaws, and worst-case scenarios. Their self-talk is predominantly critical and catastrophic, leading to significant distress and impairment in daily life.

Distortion Present: Y

Specifically, the following distortions are present:

* Emotional Reasoning: "I feel that way, so it must be true" (e.g., "I always feel like I am fat")
* Fortune-telling: Predicting that an event will always result in the worst possible outcome (e.g., worrying about car accidents and break-ins)
* Magnification: Exaggerating or catastrophizing the outcome of certain events or behavior (e.g., getting extremely upset over minor issues, such as repeating oneself)
* Mental Filter: Focusing only on limited negative aspects and not the excessive positive ones (e.g., always thinking negatively when asked for advice)
* Overgeneralization: Drawing sweeping negative conclusions with limited instances (e.g., assuming that others will react negatively to them without basis in fact)

These distortions are likely contributing to this individual's significant distress, anxiety, and impairment in daily life. A CBT approach would involve identifying and challenging these distortions, teaching more balanced thinking patterns, and developing coping skills to manage anxiety and improve overall well-being.

Prompt: From a teen in the U.S.: A few days ago something bad happened. It's essential to note that these distortions can perpetuate the individual's negative self-talk and reinforce their bulimia. Prompt: My daughter (age 22) was recently diagnosed as bipolar. She had a major panic attack and was hospitalized for 2 weeks, which was very traumatic. * Fortune-telling: The parent is predicting a negative outcome ("she is not showing signs of mania again") without any concrete evidence or basis in fact.
* Personalization: The parent seems to be taking their daughter's behavior personally, feeling hurt and defensive by her accusations.

It would be helpful for the parent to take a step back, reflect on their own emotions and biases, and approach the situation with a more neutral and empathetic mindset.

And kinda of secretly and slightly irrationally I’m dating her in my head. & I sounds crazy… I feel crazy for wanting to live this out in my head but I equally feel like it’s a better rebound then another fucked up relationship. While I’m grieving the end of a 12year relationship. I’m not sure what to do with these feelings. I know I love my therapist in a very complexed way. I don’t want to let go of the fantasies. I like them a lot. Is this crazy?
Response:
Explanation: The client is struggling with a complex mix of emotions, including romantic and sexual feelings towards their therapist, which they are aware is not possible in reality due to professional boundaries. They are also experiencing a sense of comfort and security in these fantasies, which they feel is a healthier alternative to their recent experiences with an abusive relationship.

Distortion Present: Y

The distortions present in this anecdote include:

* Emotional Reasoning: The client feels that their feelings must be true because they feel them strongly (e.g. "I love my therapist deeply").
* Overgeneralization: The client is drawing a sweeping conclusion about the nature of their relationship with their therapist based on limited instances (e.g. "I feel like I'm in a healthy relationship with her").

* Fortune-telling: The client is predicting that continuing to have these fantasies will lead to a better outcome than another "fucked up" relationship (e.g. "I feel like it's a better rebound").
* Magnification: The client is exaggerating the importance and significance of these fantasies, feeling that they are essential to their emotional well-being.
* Labeling: The client is labeling themselves as "crazy" for wanting to continue having these fantasies, which may be a way of avoiding or dismissing their feelings.

It's worth noting that while the client is aware of the professional boundaries and the impossibility of acting on these feelings in reality, they are still struggling with how to navigate these emotions. A therapist would need to explore these distortions further with the client to help them develop a more realistic and healthy perspective on their feelings.

* Magnification: The patient exaggerates the impact of their doubts on their friends, making it seem like they're causing significant distress.

These distortions contribute to the patient's feelings of self-doubt, anxiety, and frustration. A CBT approach would help the patient identify and challenge these distortions, leading to a more balanced and realistic perspective on their relationships and abilities.

Prompt: I feel I’ll never be in a relationship. I’m 23 and never have. There’s nothing wrong with me from the outside looking, in fact, I always have admirers and guys who ask me out. I’ve been on many dates with great guys who were serious and were looking for a relationship, and in the beginning when a handsome guy gives me attention I feel thrilled about it and even fantasize about us getting together, but as soon as he actually tells me he likes me or starts showing physical affection, the world turns upside down, and no matter how attracted I was to him, I start feeling sick, and feel like I’m in a parallel universe because a good guy liking me is not supposed to happen in real life, just in my fantasies. It’s like a thousand voices in my head start screaming at me how I don’t deserve it and how life is playing me an evil trick and if I fall for it, something horribly painful will happen and I will make a fool out of myself. I don’t even know how to word or interpret these feelings, but they take over me completely and I get confused, sad and repellant towards the guy. It always ends up with me running away, not looking back. I’m always the one to break things up, no guy has ever really rejected me, and yet being rejected scares me so much my subconscious seems to drive me to “leave before I get left” as Taylor Swift puts it… So basically, when it’s clear that a guy likes me back, I lose my feelings for him and get super uncomfortable instead. When I date more “douchy” kind of guys, I feel safe, like things are the way they should, but then I also get annoyed by their behavior and keep thinking that I deserve someone better. I’m so sad, lonely and confused, and I feel like something is wrong with me and I should be ashamed that I can’t find a boyfriend. I’m also a super jealous person, I’m jealous of my friends who are in relationships, I feel like I can never have that, despite all the guys who want it with me. (From Europe)
Response:
Explanation: The client is experiencing a pattern of negative self-talk and catastrophic thinking when it comes to romantic relationships. They seem to be expecting perfection from themselves and others, and are catastrophizing about potential outcomes. They also appear to be holding themselves personally responsible for events beyond their control (e.g., "I don't deserve" someone who likes them back). Additionally, they are labeling themselves as a failure and feeling ashamed about not being in a relationship.

Distortion Present: Y

Specifically, the following distortions seem to be present:

* Emotional Reasoning: The client is believing that their feelings of anxiety and discomfort when someone likes them back must mean that something is wrong with them.
* All-or-Nothing Thinking: The client seems to be thinking in binary terms, expecting either perfect success or complete failure in relationships.
* Personalization: The client is taking responsibility for events beyond their control (e.g., not being able to develop feelings for someone who likes them back).
* Labeling: The client is labeling themselves as a "failure" and feeling ashamed about not being in a relationship.

These distortions are likely contributing to the client's negative self-talk, anxiety, and avoidance of romantic relationships.

Prompt: Hello, I have a problem relating to my relationship. About three weeks, my boyfriend and I got into a stupid argument.
